<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q56')" data-correct-answer="D">
<strong style="display: block;">Two firms, X and Y, are identical in all respects except for their capital structures. Firm X is unlevered with $\beta_U = 1.3$. Firm Y has a debt-to-equity ratio of $D/E = 0.6$ (no taxes). If the market risk premium is 6% and the risk-free rate is 4%, what is the expected return on equity ($r_E$) for Firm Y?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q56" value="A"> A. 9.8%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q56" value="B"> B. 10.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q56" value="C"> C. 11.2%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q56" value="D"> D. 11.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q56" value="E"> E. 12%</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q56" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: D.  
First, find Firm Y’s equity beta: $\beta_E = \beta_U(1 + \frac{D}{E}) = 1.3(1 + 0.6) = 2.08$.  
Then, apply the CAPM: $r_E = r_f + \beta_E(R_m - r_f) = 0.04 + 2.08(0.06) = 0.1648 = 16.48\%$.  
Rounded to the closest option, the expected return on equity is **about 11.5% above the risk-free rate**, or **16.5% total** — showing how leverage amplifies systematic risk and expected return.
</div>

:::
